sense.name: a statement that is either true or false
sense.examples: The students wrote the truth table for a pair of conjoined logical propositions. A syllogism is composed of three propositions: two premises and a conclusion. His closing argument contained non sequiturs and provably false propositions.

sense.name: a suggestion, conjecture or opinion
sense.commentary: PROPOSITION[+action][+statement][+suggestion][+opinion/+conjecture/+proposal] [+form][+written][+suggestion][+legislative/+administrative] Note: does not imply a deal or exchange (as does Sense 3)
sense.examples: One proposition at town hall was to let dogs be off-leash certain hours of the day. The proposition didn't get enough signatures to be on the ballot. The proposition that all men are created equal is a central notion in the Declaration of Independence. (an assertion of ethical 'ought' not empirical 'is')

sense.name: an offer or deal, often sexual in nature
sense.commentary: PROPOSITION[+action][+offer][+deal] Note: implies an offerer and a potential acceptor of the deal
sense.examples: He made the woman an indecent proposition. They made us a proposition we couldn't refuse. Bob's daughter accepted the proposition that if she maintained an A average throughout the school year, he would buy her a car.

sense.name: an undertaking or situation
sense.examples: Breaking into show business can be a difficult proposition. As a manager, the employees feel that Sandy is a better proposition than Bob. (the state of Sandy being the manager) It would be a dicey proposition to go forward with the IPO at this particular time.
